Query: How to see log to find a boot problem

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_34718: Is there a command to see where a disk is mounted?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_34718: $ findmnt -S /dev/VG_SC/home
TARGET SOURCE                 FSTYPE OPTIONS
/home  /dev/mapper/VG_SC-home ext4   rw,relatime,errors=remount-ro,data=ordered

$ findmnt -nr -o target -S /dev/storage/home
/home
$ lsblk -o MOUNTPOINT -nr /dev/storage/home
/home

if mountpoint=$(findmnt -nr -o target -S "$device"); then
  printf '"%s" is mounted on "%s"\n' "$device" "$mountpoint"
else
  printf '"%s" does not appear to be directly mounted\n' "$device"
fi

Explanations about Options.-S:
Explicitly define the mount source. Supported specifications are device, maj:min,
 LABEL=label, UUID=uuid, PARTLABEL=label and PARTUUID=uuid.
Explanations about Options.-r:
Use raw output format. All potentially unsafe characters are hex-escaped
 (\x<code>).
Explanations about Options.-n: Do not print a header line.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Define output columns. See the --help output to get a list of the currently
 supported columns. The TARGET column contains tree formatting if the --list or
 --raw options are not specified.

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_77954: How to see Current users on the system
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_77954: who | cut -d ' ' -f 1 | sort | uniq | 
  while read user; do ps -u $user -o %u%c%a; done

Explanations about Options.-x: Display the system shutdown entries and run level changes.
Explanations about Options.-f:
Tell last to use a specific file instead of /var/log/wtmp. The --file option can
 be given multiple times, and all of the specified files will be processed.
